items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are now falling steadily. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.   
We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing debris from trash screens.

River levels are falling on the River Seven throughout the morning as rainfall eases. The forecast is for light rainfall for today 03/08/2023 and as a result we expect no flooding in the area. Further rainfall is expected later in the week and we may issue further alerts. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ings Beck, Alverthorpe Beck, Balne Beck, Oakenshaw Beck

items.message: This alert is no longer in force as the water level in Balne Beck is expected to fall through the evening and overnight. Showery outbreaks of rain on 3rd and 4th August are not expected to result in the need for further alerts in this area.

This flood alert has been issued due to high spring tides combined with strong winds. Forecast high water is 21:15 on 03/08/23 with a level of 6.47 mAOD and a Force 5 North Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. 

Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at this time, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.

The high tide on the morning of 04/08/2023 is currently forecast to be just below Flood Alert levels, however coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tides on Saturday 05/08/2023. We will update this message as necessary through the week.

This message will be updated by 15:00 on Friday, 04/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.83mAOD at 04:30 on 03/08/23 and 4.75mAOD at 16:30 on 03/08/23.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 28 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next 2 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 18:00 on 03/08/23, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are now falling steadily. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We may see further rainfall over the next few days and this Flood Alert will be re-issued if needed.
We continue to monitor the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing debris from trash screens.

Thursday afternoon's tide at 13:30 on 03/08/2023 is forecast to be approximately 20 cm lower than recent high waters, and accompanied by lighter winds and smaller waves. Tides are predicted to fall over the week ahead. However, low pressure on Saturday could see the return of some larger waves and a slightly higher than normal tide again. No more than minimal flood impacts are currently expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases.

Thursday afternoon's tide at 13:30 on 03/08/2023 is forecast to be a little lower than recent high waters, but still higher than normal due to unsettled weather. The weather increases tide table values by 0.19 m. The total forecast tide is 6.17 metres Chart Datum (3.12 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Friday's early morning tide is predicted to be 20cm lower and accompanied by smaller waves. Flood risk should reduce over the week ahead. However, low pressure on Saturday could see the return of some larger waves and minimal flood risk again. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be moved by waves. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 18:00 on 03/08/2023.

The Flood Alert has now been removed for Christchurch Harbour.
The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
Tide levels will remain high over the next 24hrs. Until then, at each high water, very minor impacts may be experienced, but we do not expect the tide to affect major roads or property.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning 04/08/2023. Areas most at risk include the Southfield farm coast. Flooding is expected at The North Sea coast from Mappleton to Spurn Point between 06:45 AM and 10:00 AM on 04/08/2023. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 04/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal flooding of areas near the Lincolnshire coastline
items.message: The risk of flooding from the high tide has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

A combination of strong winds  during spring tides, means that higher tides are expected  between 7am and 11am tomorrow morning, Friday 4th August. Flooding to the promenade is possible at these times, with large waves and sea spray overtopping likely.  Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront.  

Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. 

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  4.55mAODN at 09:00am, on Friday 4th August, which is 0.20m above tide tables, wind Force 4, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Friday 4th August at 21:45pm is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold.
Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 12pm tomorrow or earlier if conditions change.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message:
A combination of strong winds  during spring tides, means that higher tides are expected between 7am and 11am tomorrow morning, Friday 4th August.   Flooding to the promenade is possible at these times, with large waves and sea spray overtopping likely. Areas most at risk are Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton.  
The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  4.55mAODN at 09:00am, on Friday 4th August, which is 0.20m above tide tables, wind Force 4, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Friday 4th August at 21:45pm is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold.
Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 12pm tomorrow or earlier, if conditions change.

As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, we are expecting large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning 04/08/22.

Consequently, flooding of roads is possible on the high tides at 05:45 tomorrow and 07:30 tomorrow, 04/08/23. Areas most at risk are beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads

Coastal conditions are expected to continue over the next few days as we are in a period of spring tides. This Flood Alert will remain in force or be re-issued as needed.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.

Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 04/08/23, or as the situation changes.

The Flood Alert has now been removed for West Bay Harbour.
The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 01:00 PM on 03/08/2023.
Areas most at risk include the coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown and low lying land along the tidal River Stour.
Flooding is possible at coastal areas, particularly low lying land and roads nearest the sea between 11:00 AM and 03:00 PM on 03/08/2023. No property flooding is expected at this point.
Strong winds and surge are forecast over the next few days. We are expecting higher than normal tides and as a result we may issue further alerts.
We are closely monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.
This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 03/08/2023, or as the situation changes.
For those that use it, the astronomical level will be 3.22mAOD and the total water level will be 3.63mAOD.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
Coastal conditions should ease for the 03/08/2023 high tide at 14:30.    
Further high tides and strong winds are forecast over the coming days, with periods of flooding possible. We will issue further messages if required.
Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely to occur between 12:45pm and 2:45pm this afternoon, Thursday 3rd August. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.67mAODN at 1:45pm, Thursday 3rd August, which is 0.57m above tide tables, wind Force 4, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide at 02:15am on Friday 4th August is also expected to reach Flood Alert level. You are advised to stay away from risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Thursday 3rd August.

items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Tamar has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely to occur between 1:15pm and 3:15pm this afternoon, Thursday 3rd August. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge.  Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.54mAODN at 2:15pm today, Thursday 3rd August, which is 0.56m above tide tables, wind force 4, westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide at 3:00am on Friday 4th August is also expected to reach Flood Alert level. You are advised to stay away from at risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Thursday 3rd August.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely to occur between 12:45pm and 2:45pm this afternoon, Thursday 3rd August. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.67mAODN at 1:45pm, Thursday 3rd August, which is 0.57m above tide tables, wind Force 4, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide at 02:15am on Friday 4th August is also expected to reach Flood Alert level. We will update this message by 5pm today, Thursday 3rd August.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely to occur between 12:45pm and 2:45pm this afternoon, Thursday 3rd August. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.84mAODN at 1:45pm, Thursday 3rd August, which is 0.50m above tide tables, wind force 4, north - westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide at 2:15am on Friday 4th August is also expected to reach Flood Alert level. You are advised to stay away from at risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Thursday 3rd August.

items.message:
The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. The forecast is for no further significant rainfall for the rest of the day with river levels returning to normal.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent due to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible today, Thursday 03/08/2023. Areas most at risk include low lying land, roads and footpaths in the Upper Derwent around Low Marishes. Levels have peaked upstream but further light rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads which may be flooded. This message will be updated in 8 hours or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from this morning into the weekend. This is due to the natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system and recent rainfall. Current water levels will continue to remain high and may still be rising in some areas. We expect levels to drop back down to normal over the next few days. High water levels are likely at Beccles Quay. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 3rd August.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from this morning into the weekend. This is due to the natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system and recent rainfall. Current water levels will continue to remain high and may still be rising in some areas. We expect levels to drop back down to normal over the next few days. High water levels are likely in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Friday 3rd August.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
As a result of spring tides, water levels will be at their highest this evening.

Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton. 

The detailed tidal information for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.43 mAODN at 09:45 PM on 03/08/2023, which is 0.01 m above tide tables, with north-westerly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.) We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings.

We are closing flood gates at Pill and Shirehampton. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

We will remove this message by 09:00 AM on 04/08/2023.

As a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Tides will be at their highest between 8pm and 10pm today, 03/08/23. Flooding of roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  A series of high tides is due over the next 2 days. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.3m to 7.5m Thursday evening and 7.1-7.2m Friday morning.  Newport 7.1m to 7.2m Thursday evening and 6.7m-6.9m  Friday morning, 04/08/23
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please stay away from large waves as they are dangerous.  
This message will be updated  by 10:00 on 04/08/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames

items.message:
A high tide of 4.74m is expected at Richmond at around 4:45PM on Thursday 3 August, followed by another high tide of 4.91m at around 5:30AM on Friday 4 August.

Due to high fluvial flows coming down the River Crane, the Crane Tidal Gates may not be able to close to hold back the incoming tides from the River Thames. As a result, the incoming tides will flow up the River Crane which, when combined with the fluvial flow already in the channel, will push levels very high. Some flooding of gardens and low lying land is expected around Isleworth, although we do not expect any flooding to buildings.

Flooding is expected to affect Talbot Road, Percy Road, Napier Road, Haliburton Road, Eve Road and the Northcote Road footbridge. Any flooding is likely to be of short duration covering the period around high tide.

We will be closely monitoring the situation throughout the day and this message will be updated as the situation changes.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, or earlier if the situation changes.
